raw_text:
No to Royal succession shake-up
 
 A Labour peer has withdrawn proposals to give female members of the Royal Family the same rights as males.
 
 The legislation would have ended the right of male heirs with older sisters to succeed to the Crown. It would also have torn up ancient legislation banning heirs to the throne marrying Roman Catholics. But the government refused to back Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill, saying it was too complex and raised too many constitutional issues.
 
 The Lord Chancellor, Lord Falconer, agreed the 1701 Act of Settlement, which governs the succession, was discriminatory but added that "for all practical purposes its effects are limited".
 
 The changes proposed by Lord Dubs were a "complex and controversial undertaking raising major constitutional issues", he said. Lord Falconer said there were 22 members of the Royal Family in the line of succession after the Prince of Wales - all of who were eligible to succeed and had been unaffected by the act. "It is not a simple matter that can be tinkered with lightly. While we wish to remove all forms of discrimination... this isn't the proper form," he added.
 
 He did not rule out change in the future but said if Lord Dubs' private member's bill was passed by peers, he would urge MPs to oppose it in the Commons. Lord Dubs agreed to withdraw his bill after its second reading in the House of Lords, but urged the government to think again at a later stage. "We cannot forever say we don't want to change things because it is too difficult," he told peers. During the debate, the Labour peer and former minister said: "The monarchy should symbolise the values of this country. "What we don't want is a situation where the values of the country have moved on and the monarchy is centuries behind the times. "We are surely all opposed to discrimination on the grounds of gender and we are surely also opposed to discrimination against Catholics." But opponents of the bill, including Tory Lord Campbell of Alloway and the Bishop of Winchester, the Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, said it would separate the state from both the Church of England and the Christian faith. Such a "secular" state would be markedly "less tolerant", Rt Rev Scott-Joynt argued.
llama3.2:1b: A Labour peer has withdrawn his proposal to give female members of the Royal Family equal rights with males in succession, citing constitutional issues. The government had refused to back the bill, which would have allowed older sisters to succeed to the Crown if they were Roman Catholic. The Lord Chancellor agreed that the 1701 Act of Settlement, which governs the line of succession, was discriminatory but its effects are limited for practical purposes. A Labour peer had argued that changing the law would be a "complex and controversial undertaking" raising constitutional issues, and urged the government to consider it again in the future.
llama3.2:3b: A Labour peer withdrew his bill to give female members of the Royal Family the same rights as males, citing complexity and constitutional issues. The Lord Chancellor agreed that the 1701 Act of Settlement is discriminatory but said it can't be changed lightly. The government refused to back the bill, with one MP urging them to reconsider in the future.
gemma2:2b: A Labour peer withdrew his bill to change the British royal succession laws. The bill sought to end male heir's rights to the throne and remove restrictions on marriage for heirs of the throne.  The government opposed the bill, citing its complexity and constitutional concerns, while also acknowledging the discriminatory nature of existing legislation.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Labour peer who proposed changing the Royal Family's rights to male heirs with older sisters withdrew his proposal, saying it was too complex and raised constitutional issues. Lord Falconer, the Lord Chancellor, agreed that the 1701 Act of Settlement governing succession was discriminatory but added that for practical purposes, its effects are limited. The government said they would not back Lord Dubs' bill, which sought to change the Act. Lord Falconer disagreed with Lord Dubs and urged MPs not to oppose his private member's bill after second reading in the House of Lords.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A Labour peer withdrew his bill to change the royal succession laws after the House of Lords rejected it due to complexity and constitutional issues, with some MPs calling for opposition if passed.
qwen2.5:3b: A Labour peer withdrew proposals to give female members of the Royal Family equal succession rights, as proposed in Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill. The government rejected the bill due to its complexity and constitutional issues. Lord Falconer stated that while discriminatory laws like the 1701 Act of Settlement are seen as unfair, they do not significantly impact modern succession rules. Labour peer Lord Dubs agreed to withdraw his bill but urged for reconsideration later, arguing the monarchy should symbolize current values. Opponents suggested such changes would separate state and religion, making it less tolerant, with critics including Tory Lord Campbell of Alloway and Bishop Michael Scott-Joynt.

No Royal succession shake-up

A Labour peer has withdrawn proposals to give female members of the Royal Family the same rights as males. 

The legislation would have ended the right of male heirs with older sisters to succeed to the Crown, and it would also torn up ancient legislation banning heirs to the throne marrying Roman Catholics.

But the government refused to back Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill, saying it was too complex and raised too many constitutional issues.

During the debate, Lord Dubs' private member's bill was withdrawn after its second reading in the House of Lords. He urged the government to think again at a later stage if it were passed by peers. "We cannot forever say we don't want to change things because it is too difficult," he told peers.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. The main points are:

1. No to Royal succession shake-up - the legislation would have ended the right of male heirs with older sisters to succeed to the Crown.
2. The legislation would have torn up ancient legislation banning heirs to the throne marrying Roman Catholics.
3. Lord Falconer agreed that the 1701 Act of Settlement, which governs the succession, is discriminatory but added that "for all practical purposes its effects are limited".
4. The changes proposed by Lord Dubs were a "complex and controversial undertaking raising major constitutional issues", he said.
5. While we wish to remove all forms of discrimination... this isn't the proper form - there are 22 members of the Royal Family in the line of succession after the Prince of Wales - all of whom are eligible to succeed and have been affected by the act.
6. If Lord Dubs' private member's bill was passed by peers, he would urge MPs to oppose it in the Commons.
7. The Labour peer and former minister said: "The monarchy should symbolise the values of this country" - what we don't want is a situation where the values of the country have moved on and the monarchy is centuries behind the times.
8. We are surely all opposed to discrimination on the grounds of gender and we are surely also opposed to discrimination against Catholics.
9. Such a "secular" state would be markedly "less tolerant", Rt Rev Scott-Joynt argued - this is a key point in understanding the context of the text.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let's break this down. The user wants me to summarize a given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. They specifically mentioned outputting only the summary in plain text without any explanations or formatting.

First, I need to read through the provided text carefully. It's about a UK government move regarding female members of the Royal Family. The Labour peer is withdrawing proposals to give them equal succession rights compared to their male counterparts.

The summary should capture the main points: the withdrawal of proposals, the effects on male heirs and the legacy monarchy, the government's refusal to back Lord Dubs' bill, and some background on Lord Falconer's stance regarding the 1701 Act of Settlement. He mentions it being discriminatory but limiting its effects.

I also need to include his decision not to rule out future changes, especially if the Bill is passed in the Lords. There's a mention that Labour peers will urge MPs against the bill after its second reading. Additionally, the debate highlights concerns about separating the state from both Church of England and Christian faith, which are secularists.

I should make sure the summary is concise, avoiding any unnecessary details, while covering all these points clearly.
</think>

No to Royal succession shake-up: A Labour peer has withdrawn proposals for equal succession rights for female Royal Family members. The bill would end male heirs' succession and affect the legacy monarchy. The government refused support for Lord Dubs' bill, which aimed to remove discrimination on gender and oppose Catholic influences. Lord Falconer supported the 1701 Act but dismissed it as discriminatory yet limited by its effects. He agreed not to rule out future changes unless passed in Lords, and Labour peers called for MPs to oppose the bill after its second reading. The bill would create a "secular" state rejecting both Church of England and Christian faith norms.
tinyllama:1.1b: After rejecting a proposal to give female members of the Royal Family the same rights as male heirs, a Labour peer has withdrawn his private member's bill aimed at ending the "discriminatory" legacy of the 1701 Act governing the succession. The Bill had aimed to change the 1701 Act to make it easier for the Prince of Wales and future royal children to succeed the monarchy, but Lord Falconer, the Lord Chancellor, argued that this was "too complex" and "raised major constitutional issues". However, Lord Dubs had withdrawn his Bill following his second reading in the House of Lords. He urged the government to reconsider at a later stage and suggested a compromise by allowing female heirs equal rights alongside male ones, but conservatives warned against this move. They argued that separating the state from both Christianity and the Church of England would be "less tolerant" and that it would create more secular states which were markedly "less tolerant".
tinydolphin:1.1b: The proposal to change the rules for the British monarchy did not receive favorable reviews, with some suggesting that it goes too far in favoring male heirs and others questioning its constitutionality. The current ruling party insists on maintaining the status quo, stating that there is already a "compromise" in place. However, the bill proposed by Lord Dubs (formerly a Labour peer) would have introduced gender-neutral inheritance rights for the royal family and allowed Roman Catholics to marry into the line of succession. Critics argue that this move may signal a change in values for the monarchy, which has historically been seen as representing the values of the country. The proposed bill also includes amendments that would address constitutional issues, such as the 1701 Act of Settlement and its effects on the future of succession. However, some argue that these changes may only serve to limit constitutional rights rather than truly addressing the issue of discrimination against Catholics in the monarchy.
phi:2.7b: A Labour peer withdrew proposals to give female members of the Royal Family the same rights as males. The government said it was too complex and raised constitutional issues. The bill, if passed by peers, would have torn up ancient legislation banning Roman Catholic heirs from succeeding to the throne. However, the Lords rejected the bill after Lord Dubs agreed to withdraw it. He urged the government to change it at a later stage but did not rule out future changes. The proposal was opposed by some who argued that it would separate the state from both the Church of England and Christian faith.

Lord Dubs agreed to withdraw his bill after its second reading in the House of Lords but urged the government to think again at a later stage. The text also mentions that opponents of the bill argued that separating the state from the Church of England and the Christian faith would be markedly less tolerant.

Lord Dubs' bill withdrawn after second reading, but he urged government to reconsider future changes.

granite3.1-dense:2b: A Labour peer, Lord Dubs, proposed legislation to equalize female members of the Royal Family's succession rights with males, effectively ending male heirs' priority over older sisters and abolishing restrictions on Catholic marriages for those in line to the throne. However, this bill was withdrawn after facing opposition from the government, which deemed it overly complex and raised significant constitutional concerns. The Lord Chancellor, Lord Falconer, acknowledged the 1701 Act of Settlement as discriminatory but emphasized its limited practical effects. Despite this, he advised MPs to oppose the bill if passed by the House of Lords. Lord Dubs urged reconsideration at a later stage due to societal values favoring non-discrimination. Opponents, including Conservative Lord Campbell and the Bishop of Winchester, argued that such changes would alienate the state from both the Church of England and Christian faith, potentially leading to a less tolerant society.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Labour peer Lord Dubs withdrew his bill proposing equal succession rights for female royals and allowing heirs to marry Roman Catholics after the government refused to back it, citing constitutional complexity. Lord Chancellor Lord Falconer acknowledged the 1701 Act of Settlement was discriminatory but argued its practical effects were limited. He warned that altering royal succession was a major constitutional issue and urged MPs to oppose the bill if passed by peers. While Lord Dubs insisted the monarchy should reflect modern values, opponents, including Tory Lord Campbell of Alloway and the Bishop of Winchester, argued the bill would weaken ties between the state and the Church of England.
reference: He did not rule out change in the future but said if Lord Dubs' private member's bill was passed by peers, he would urge MPs to oppose it in the Commons.But the government refused to back Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill, saying it was too complex and raised too many constitutional issues.The changes proposed by Lord Dubs were a "complex and controversial undertaking raising major constitutional issues", he said.But opponents of the bill, including Tory Lord Campbell of Alloway and the Bishop of Winchester, the Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, said it would separate the state from both the Church of England and the Christian faith.Lord Falconer said there were 22 members of the Royal Family in the line of succession after the Prince of Wales - all of who were eligible to succeed and had been unaffected by the act.The Lord Chancellor, Lord Falconer, agreed the 1701 Act of Settlement, which governs the succession, was discriminatory but added that "for all practical purposes its effects are limited".Lord Dubs agreed to withdraw his bill after its second reading in the House of Lords, but urged the government to think again at a later stage.
